Fields.DialogueText: Gneisenau? May I speak with you, please?
Of course, Kapitän. I assume this is about the Inspector and his men?
Yes. You were there when word came through, after all.
I was, but I was a bit distracted.
Tell me again how that works, you being distracted and all. I thought you were present wherever you were present, if you know what I mean.
I do, and I am, but nothing is ever that simple, is it? I'm present where my body is, but I also have...feelings...around the ship.
Like the strands of a spider's web?
Not the analogy I would have used, but yes, that will work. My consciousness is like the web, the spider my physical body, and the strands are...are...

Fields.MenuText: Areas of concentration among the crew?
Shivering strings of fear?
The last vestiges of a failing mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Flattery will get you everywhere, Kapitän.
Fear is for the weak, Kapitän, and I am decidedly strong.
I'd answer that, but I'm far too frail to think.
I'll take that under advisement. Meanwhile, we...
Captain, Morganas off the port.
@BATTLE
Good answer.
Kapitän, I think we need to talk about the inspection.
What's there to discuss? They'll come, they'll see how things really are here, and they'll go back without any problems.
Really, that simple? You didn't seem that calm about it a while back, what changed?
Your comment about the spider in her web has me thinking. This Inspector...instead of us treating him like the spider coming to devour us, we should be thinking the other way.
Like he's the fly coming into our web? I like that. Can I be the bloodsucking fiend?

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't have it any other way.
You said it, not me.
Agreed– there's no reason to switch roles now.

Fields.DialogueText: Neither would...hey!
Yes, I did. Did you not hear me?
Pray you don't wake up in my web one day, Kapitän.
Then it's agreed?
Absolutely. I will be the spider tugging out the fly of the Inspector.
All we need to do now is lay out the web and wait for dinner to come to us.
I like the sound of that.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, I just heard from the bridge... It appears the Inspector from Command and his men are on their way. I hear he's German.
Which means this is more complicated than if he was Swiss. Neutrality fleet or no, our German crew members need to be at their most proper while he's here.
That goes for certain German Belles too, I might add.
Certain German Belles are never improper, Kapitän.
Uh–huh. How is it you heard about... Wait, let me guess, your web?
Machiavelli would be proud.
"It is necessary to be a fox to discover the snares?" At the risk of mixing metaphors.
Kapitän. You've been reading!
I love that edge of shock in your voice.
No need to be... Hold on a moment... Kapitän, there's something...
Morganas spotted!
Something else is wrong, Kapitän. I think I need to be somewhere else right now.

Fields.MenuText: To hell with that, you're needed on the bridge!
More important than fighting Morganas? I'm sorry, you're needed on the bridge.
Later, Gneisenau; right now we're both needed elsewhere.

Fields.DialogueText: Dammit, don't doubt my instincts...
You're right, Morganas come first.
I understand, Kapitän. We should get moving.
Come on, let's go.
@BATTLE
I mean, yes, Kapitän.
So what was that very important thing you needed to tell me about?
I heard something in another part of the ship that had my attention, but by the time the battle was over, the thing was gone.
Thing? That's a little vague for you.
I know, and it's making me crazy! I know it was something important, but it isn't like I have a record of everything I hear or should hear.
Is that something you can do?
I just said I couldn't.
No, you said you don't have one, not that you couldn't have one. If that's something you could develop, it would be extremely handy.
Well, I can't, so you'll just have to accept me as I am.

Fields.MenuText: When have I ever done anything else?
Accept you as you... Are you feeling well?
I always have accepted you as you are...a severe pain in my backside.

Fields.DialogueText: Never, actually. You've been very good that way, thank you.
Fine enough for someone who can't get my point across.
You're no bucket of sweet cream either, Kapitän.
So now that that's out of the way, may we continue, please?
You're right, Kapitän, I'm sorry. It's just like I need to sneeze or something - the thing I need to know is just out of reach and I can't get it back. If only I could...
Morganas inbound and moving fast!
With any luck, it'll come to you after the battle.
@BATTLE
I wish you had let me know you were on board, Herr Inspector. I would have given you a proper welcome.
And announced my presence to everyone on board? No, this way is better in my experience, Kapitän.
Very effective, Herr Inspector.
Just Inspector, Kapitän. Were you not briefed on that?
We were. I only wished to give you your proper honorific.
When you say 'I', don't you mean 'we'? Where is the Belle, Kapitän?
I assume you mean me, Inspector?
Indeed, I do. I have a few questions for you.
Inspector, respectfully, this may not be the correct time.
Are you hindering my investigation, Kapitän?
Of course not. Quite the opposite, in fact. You see, as I believe we are about to hear from the intercom–
Morganas approaching. Battle stations!
Excuse me, we're needed.
Of course.
Now that he's gone, what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: It's too soon to tell.
He's clearly power hungry.
I think he likes you. That could work to our advantage.

Fields.DialogueText: Good point. Let's collect some evidence before forming an opinion.
Like the damn Russians. We'll have to treat him as carefully as one.
Don't even think of turning me into a Parisian perfume artist, Kapitän.
No matter what we think, we'll have to treat him well or find ourselves in rather uncomfortable positions, yes?
My thoughts exactly, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
You still don't think the Inspector's covert arrival was the dangerous thing you heard?
No, especially since a few more things have tickled my strands.
You know, I believe we're going to have to work on your phrasing soon.
Now isn't the time, Kapitän. There's something important going on, and I need to figure it out before the pincers encircle us and turn this into a pure cauldron.
What makes you think whatever is bothering you is so dangerous it could annihilate us?
Belle's intuition, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: All right, I trust you.
That's not as comforting as I'd like, but it'll do.
Keep that superstitious nonsense off my ship, Gneisenau. Facts only, please.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kapitän, that means more to me than I can say.
It'll have to. Sorry.
As you wish, Kapitän.
Now, with your permission, I'm going to allow myself to be a bit more diffuse while I work on this. It might make me a bit forgetful, but I'll try to keep it manageable.
Permission granted, but be careful. If what's disturbing you is dangerous, you shouldn't take any unnecessary risks.
Existence is an unnecessary risk in some ways, Kapitän. Better this than the opposite.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Any luck yet?
Hmm? What did you say? Ah, any luck? Hmm... No, not really.
Is this part of the diffusion you were talking about? I didn't think it would have such an effect on you.
Yes... Well...it does. I... There it is again! I feel something tickling around in my bowels.
All right, remember what I said last time about us working on your phrasing?
NOT NOW!

Fields.MenuText: SNAP OUT OF IT, GNEISENAU!
DO NOT BARK AT THE CAPTAIN!
Excuse me?

Fields.DialogueText: AAAARRRRrrrrgggghh.... All right, what, wait?
RAAAAR! I CAN'T... Aaa....
YOU HEARD ME, I... Wait... Ugh....
I'm sorry, Kapitän, I just... There it is again!
Perhaps it would be best if I left you alone?
What? Oh, yes, if you don't...
Captain to the bridge, Morganas spotted and closing fast!
I need you with me, Gneisenau. Can I count on you?
I... always, Kapitän. I'm here. Let's go.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, I...
Privacy, Gneisenau! I'm in the head!
No time for pleasantries! I've discovered an assassin on board! Someone wants to kill the Inspector!
What?! Who?
I don't know. I... Oh, no!
Gneisenau? Gneisenau, where did you go? Gneisenau?
*sigh* I'd better see if I can track her down.
*ALARM*
Of course.
@BATTLE
I have already informed the Fuhrer about this, little Belle. He was most pleased with your action.
Please pass on my regards to the Fuhrer, Inspector. I did what anyone here would have done in my place. I only wish I could have caught the assassin too.
False modesty fails you, Gneisenau; no one could have done what you did. Appearing before the Inspector just as the bullet would have hit him and taking it in your own flesh? Amazing.
As amazing as it sounds, you should have seen it in person. It is a moment I will never forget. She just reached out and grabbed the bullet.

Fields.MenuText: That's amazing!
Yes, so I've heard... three times now.
I don't care what you say, I still don't believe it.

Fields.DialogueText: *whispers* Thank you, Kapitän.
*whispers* No less true for the retelling.
*whispers* That's your problem, not mine.
Well, much as that interests me, it is Command's opinion which matters most. I'll be sending them a full report.
If you were interested, you might even be able to move up in the world.
What does that mean, moving up? I don't understand.
It means that the Fuhrer may call you to Berlin. Someone who can stop a bullet would make an excellent bodyguard.
Somehow, I don't see Command being willing to give Gneisenau up.
You would be surprised, the influence of some, Kapitän. Now excuse me, I have a report to file.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, for the last time, I can't leave the ship!
I understand your concern, Gneisenau, but I can't really talk about this right now.
You've been avoiding me ever since the Inspector made his silly little statement.
It's not silly, that's the problem. I believe he meant every word of it.
But you know better than anyone that I can't leave the ship.
What I know and what the Inspector believes are two different things.
Kapitän, you can't let this happen. You know how far my range extends. What if they tried forcing me out? Would I...die?

Fields.MenuText: Always with the drama!
It won't happen, stop panicking!
I know, it's frightening. We won't let it happen like that.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm dramatic because I'm nervous!
This isn't panicking! You'll know panicking when you see it!
Frightening isn't half of what I'm feeling.
Well then, what's your plan?
Simple. We let him fail.
Let him fail? How does that...
Captain, Morganas inbound.
@BATTLE
Care to explain to me how this plan will go?
It will go well, thank you.
Is that not enough?
This isn't funny.

Fields.MenuText: No, it isn't. I apologize.
Come on...a little funny.
Your sense of humor needs adjusting. That was hilarious.

Fields.DialogueText: I accept. Let's move on.
Well...maybe a little, but not much.
Hilarious, no. Out of bounds, possibly.
Thankfully, your humor isn't the focus of your plan, correct? At least, I hope it isn't.
No, it isn't, don't worry. This is one of those plans that doesn't require me to do much of anything except let nature take its course.
You're going to...seduce the Inspector?
What? Where did you... No, that's not what that means at all!
That's what it normally means, doesn't it?
Well, no...what? I...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So has nature taken its course yet?
Not yet, and can we please use a different phrase?
Why are you so squirrely about this?
I'm not... Wait, squirrely? Where did that come from?
After I saw how strange you acted over the 'take its course' phrase, I thought I should try a few others out to see what they do.
What? Since when did I become a science experiment?
The same day you decided to make a plan revolving around the idea of "let the Inspector fail!"
So this is all just an elaborate payback? That's...that's....
Yes? That's....

Fields.MenuText: Pretty hilarious, actually.
Pathetic, truly pathetic.
Childish.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you see it my way.
And now you know how I felt.
Considering I never had a childhood, I'm going to ignore that.
Though now that I think about it, on a scale of harshness, this ranks pretty low. Still, we shouldn't have to do this to each other just to get our points across.
We... Uh oh, I know that look.
Indeed.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Kapitän, I may have a lead on the assassin.
Good. I've been trying to keep that off my scope and let you do your thing, but I have to admit, it's been creeping up on me recently.
Well, I've been going over what I know in my mind and thought a fresh bit of brainpower would help. Care to join me?

Fields.MenuText: Time with you is always a pleasure.
I'll work it into my schedule, sure.
If I have to, then I'll make it happen.

Fields.DialogueText: I only wish everyone saw it that way.
Well, don't stress yourself or anything.
You really know how to make a girl feel special, don't you?
Anyway... Let's continue. You were saying?
Thank you, Kapitän. The first thing is...
Ah, Inspector, so good to see you.
And you, Belle. Kapitän, a word?
Anything you have to say to me you can say in front of Gneisenau. She's earned the right.
Even when it directly impacts her future?
Especially then.
Please, Inspector, go on.
I've word from the Fuhrer, Kapitän. It seems that...
Captain to the bridge. Morganas reported.
@BATTLE
And you haven't seen him since?
Not physically. I know where he is, of course, but as I'm putting what power I have not focused on the ship's safety into the assassin hunt, I can't keep track of his pursuits.
A particularly convoluted way of saying you can't do too many things at once.
I liked the way I said it.
You would.
What was that?

Fields.MenuText: Relax, Gneisenau. Not everything is an insult.
Please, Gneisenau, don't misunderstand me. I need you calm.
Calm down, Gneisenau!

Fields.DialogueText: It sure sounds like it when said under your breath!
I am calm. Intensely angry, but calm.
Your tone isn't really helping!
Nevertheless, Kapitän, I will take your request under advisement. My watchword for the day will be "calm."
Good thing too. Do you see what I see over there?
Only if you're also seeing Morganas.
I am. Come on, if we hurry we can get a jump on the bridge announcement.
@BATTLE
You're in a foul mood, Gneisenau. What's shaking your strands?
Strands? Are we back to the spider analogy again?
Again? I didn't think we ever left it, and yes, we're there again.
I just caught the Inspector making another call into OKW. He very pointedly asked me to leave once he saw me and went so far as to order me not to listen in.
I didn't know he could order you like that.
My loyalty to Germany compels me to follow his orders.
Hmm...this may present a bit of a problem to my plan.
Ah, yes. The infamous plan...good to know that it's working so well so far!

Fields.MenuText: This isn't the right time for sarcasm, Gneisenau.
Your flattery is like honey, Gneisenau, and your sarcasm like vinegar.
Toss all the sarcasm at me you want, it still won't change anything.

Fields.DialogueText: You've never cared for my sarcasm...or my feelings.
Then I'll pour the one and stay the other...though you won't know which is which.
At least I'll feel better for saying it.
And isn't that what this is all about?
Now who's being sarcastic?
Captain to the bridge!
Saved by the bridge.
So to speak.
@BATTLE
Things are starting to fall into place, Kapitän.
I agree. Based on these duty rosters, I think we can safely cross these names off the list of potential assassins and put them firmly on the "safe" list.
Agreed. Unfortunately, most of the ones left are in highly sensitive jobs.
We're in the middle of a war, if not two wars, Gneisenau. All jobs are highly sensitive.
You know what I mean, Kapitän. There's a difference between boiler technician and helmsman.

Fields.MenuText: Everyone is in service to Command.
Not to an enemy bullet there isn't.
Not when it comes to betrayal.

Fields.DialogueText: I know you're not questioning my loyalty, Kapitän.
Depending on where the bullet strikes, yes. Yes, there is.
That's like comparing spoiled milk to poison gas; one is worse than the other, right?
Why all the stress? Are you...
Uh oh, I...yes, here it comes.
Captain to the bridge, captain to the bridge.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, during that last attack I discovered something. It seems that our assassin is operating mostly during times like this, taking advantage of our temporary distraction.
Hmm... Yes, that's what I would do if I were an assassin.
More importantly, why didn't I think of it? I'm the strategist here.
Perhaps it's a compliment that you don't have the devious mind needed for this line of work. Regardless, is this something we should bring the Inspector in on?
I can't imagine why. Our crew, our problem, correct?

Fields.MenuText: Normally, yes... But for a spy, no.
I'm sorry, but I don't want anything more to do with this than I have to.
No, not even a little. Turn this over to the Inspector.

Fields.DialogueText: So he gets the assassin, just like that?
So he gets what he wants and we just have to watch?
And you think this is an act of bravery, rather than cowardice?
Put simply? Yes. In fact, if we're lucky, letting him catch the assassin will satisfy his desire to take something back to the Fuhrer, something that isn't you.
Ooohhh... I like how you're thinking. All right, let's bring him in.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
So you think you've found the assassin? The two of you, succeeding where I have not?
You mean the kapitän of the ship and a powerful entity embodying the essence of the Reich's power? Us two?
Gneisenau, remember that the Inspector is our guest and as such deserves a bit of courtesy.
Every courtesy, I'd say.
Saving your life seemed pretty courteous to me.

Fields.MenuText: Careful, Inspector. She has a point.
There are better ways to bring that up, Gneisenau.
What she's trying to say is...well, yes, she said it.

Fields.DialogueText: *whispers* Thank you, Kapitän.
*whispers* But not more satisfactory ones.
*whispers* Damn right, I did.
Hmm... As impolitic as it was, she does have a point. All right, give me the list and I'll take a look at it.
We were hoping for a bit more than that, actually.
More than my attention? Truly, Kapitän, how much more did you wish?
Morganas off the port, all hands battle stations.
@BATTLE
I see you've narrowed down the list considerably, Inspector.
You do good work, Kapitän. Well, you and the Belle.
Thank you for remembering me, Inspector.
I can't forget you, not ever. Now, if you don't mind, my men and I will take over the assassin hunt from here.
Of course, Inspector. Thank you, Inspector.
What was that? You're just letting him take over the investigation?
Of course I am. It's what we discussed, isn't it?
Well, yes, but I...

Fields.MenuText: Ah, ah, no buts.
Trust me, Gneisenau, trust me.
For once, can we remember who is captain and who is not?

Fields.DialogueText: And no regrets either? Fine, but why?
I do, but I still don't understand why he gets it.
Yes. Kapitän. Of. Course. Kapitän. But why, Kapitän?
Because now you can turn all your attention to following him.
I can't, remember? His orders?
I have a way around that too. We... Uh oh, the engines are pushing up. We must have spotted Morganas.
@BATTLE
This is ridiculous, you know. It won't work.
Have faith, of course it will work.
How does writing a letter overrule the power of the Inspector?
Because it will go to the Fuhrer himself, thus bypassing the Inspector's implied power.
But it won't arrive until the Inspector does.
Exactly, by which time it will no longer be needed.
I'm confused, really I am.

Fields.MenuText: Well, that's nothing new.
Isn't it enough that I say it will work?
The only other option is to flat give up.

Fields.DialogueText: You want something new? I'll give you something... *sigh*...Fine.
Anyone else, no; you... Fine.
Now that's something you know I won't do!
Excellent. Now, please deliver this to the Inspector.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
What can I say, Kapitän? When you're right, you're right.
Thank you, Gneisenau. I'd like to think I was exceptionally inspired on this one.
Are you sure you can't explain to me how a letter that hasn't been delivered frees me up to do my spying... Ugh, I hate that word.
All you need to know is that it works. Tell me, did you learn anything from our Inspector's radio traffic?
I did, only... I don't really want to tell you.
You don't... Gneisenau, I thought we trusted each other by now.
We do, we do... It's just that I don't want to hurt you with this.

Fields.MenuText: What do you take me for, an infant? Tell me already!
Your concern touches me, really, but you need to tell me.
Much as I'd prefer to avoid pain, I need to know.

Fields.DialogueText: All right, all right, don't say I didn't warn you.
My concern is for the health of you and the ship, but all right.
I'm sorry if this hurts, but I respect you as my commanding officer. Very well.
The Inspector thinks he's discovered the assassin. It's one of the bridge crew.
WHAT?!?
See, I knew this was going to happen. Kapitän, we...
Morganas spotted, Morganas...
Is that him? Is that the one?
Please, Kapitän, we have a job to do first. Come on, Kapitän, come on!
@BATTLE
And that is the last of my evidence. Do you have any questions, Kapitän?
None other than how he managed to get this far for this long on my ship.
He was rather ingenious, really. Surely he had assistance from one nation or another.
I don't care, as long as he's off my deck by morning.
Well, since my work here is mostly done, that won't be a problem. Still, there is the lingering question about your place here.
There's no question. My place is here.
I'm still not certain I see it that way.

Fields.MenuText: You'll have to, Inspector. She stays here.
Well get some glasses, Inspector. She stays here.
Much as I'd sometimes like to see her go, she can't.

Fields.DialogueText: YES!
I'm so happy I could kiss you!
Thanks... I think.
Your loyalty to your crew is admirable, Kapitän. The Fuhrer will hear of it.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well, Kapitän, I see you've broken out the books.
I have. It's been a while since I've been able to read, and you've interested me in the topic enough that I thought I'd get a head start.
That's something I love about you, Kapitän... The way you throw yourself into something.
Interesting choice of words, Gneisenau. I thought we were going to work on your phrasing?
What choice, Kapitän?
Something you "love" about me.
I...well...um...

Fields.MenuText: Oh, come on, Gneisenau. I'm just jangling your web!
I mean, not that I... You know... Maybe we should just....
It was a joke, Gneisenau. Don't panic.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, well... Excuse me, I have to go.
Just, yes, good idea... Excuse me.
Panic? No one's panicking! Excuse me!
Gneisenau, wait, I...
I have to go!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'd like to discuss something I read about regarding Hannibal's strategy at Cannae.
You want to talk about strategy?
I said I did, didn't I? What's gotten into you these last few...well, what's gotten into you?
Tell me something, Kapitän. Are you interested in this because I'm interested, or are you getting something different out of our discussions?

Fields.MenuText: They make me a better Captain, that's it.
A little bit of both, actually.
I...just enjoy our talks, really.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, thank you for your honesty, Kapitän.
Nothing wrong with that, I suppose.
I'm flattered, Kapitän, truly I am.
So what's this about then? What's with the...
Morganas spotted, Captain to the bridge.
Well, at least we know this one isn't an assassin. Shall we, Kapitän?
@BATTLE
What's this, Gneisenau? You're delivering my dinner for the night?
No, Kapitän. This is a treat. A gift. A thank you gift, as it were.
Hmm...two glasses and a bottle of...is that cognac?
I was told this is particularly good. I haven't broken the seal yet, so I can't speak to its condition.
What's the occasion?
Celebrating the good times while we can, Kapitän. We've been through a lot, you and I, and even though we've only known each other for a short time....
It feels much longer, doesn't it?
Yes, it does. Anyway, I was hoping we could crack this open and drink together not as crewmates, but as friends...though honestly I feel as if we've become... more?
More than friends? Do you mean...
Ah...well, I...
I... I think I know what you mean..
I feel the same way...
